title.narrative: Demonstration of BAT and BEP in fossil fuel-fired utilities and industrial boilers in response to the Stockholm Convention on Peristent Organic Pollutants (POPs)

description.narrative:
In accordance with the relevant resolutions of the third session of the Conference of the Parties (COP3) of the Stockholm Convention (SC) the project overall objective aims at reducing and, where feasible, eliminating unintentionally produced POPs (UP-POPs) releases in two main source categories specified in Annex C of the SC document – fossil fuel-fired utilities and industrial boilers.
The project aims at the formulation and/or enhancement of relevant guidelines and guidance on best available techniques and best environmental practices (BAT/BEP) for fossil fuel-fired utilities and industrial boilers by addressing specific features of industry, common practices in the region and related socio-economic considerations. The regional guidelines and guidance on BAT/BEP will fully incorporate the regional experience gained through pollution prevention/cleaner production (PP/CP) measures. The immediate objective of the project aims at establishing UP-POPs baseline inventories in fossil fuel-fired utilities and industrial boilers source category achieved by specifically designed sectoral studies and targeted capacity building.
Pilot demonstration cases have been identified based on the initial survey conducted in this source category in the participating countries and based on initial calculations, are envisaged to reduce a conservative approximation of 6.23 gTEQ dioxin emission. As no emission factors for the industrial boilers source category are reported in the UNEP Toolkit, the missing emission factors that should be used and are widely needed to quantify the dioxin emissions in the developing countries where industrial boilers are dominantly used in various manufacturing processes, had to be identified. Hence emission factors from other references were selected and applied in the initial calculations (particularly focusing on prevailing conditions in Cambodia as an example of an LDC in this region). Explanatory notes on the pilot demonstration cases and assumptions and references used are given in Annex 7. Measurements of dioxin emissions during the planned pilot demonstration case studies will provide more reliable figures that will be used to accurately define the necessary emission factors for industrial boilers and maybe incorporated in the UNEP Toolkit.
In addition, the project also targets the identification of possible options for the simultaneous reduction of dioxins and C02 from fossil fuel-fired utility and industrial boilers in response to Stockholm Convention and Climate Change requirements as presented in Annex 8. While it focuses on the introduction of BAT/BEP measures, it also considers increasing energy efficiency, as required in Annex C Part V B (a)(iv) of the Convention. Costs benefit assessment of various BAT/BEP options reflecting a significant linkage between the reduction of UP-POPs and green house gas emissions has also been carried out.
The scope of this project also incorporates the promotion of technology transfer and investment by identification and implementation of innovative mechanisms for public-private partnership (PPP) ensuring the sustainability of the project.
